jeopardy_round: IT WAS A VERY GOOD YEAR

(1, 1).clue: Prohibition was repealed in this year, the first year of FDR's first term

(2, 1).clue: In "Monty Python & the Holy Grail", a woman is weighed against this fowl to see whether she's a witch

(3, 1).clue: This Indiana city near the University of Notre Dame was once home to the Studebaker Automobile Co.

(4, 1).clue: Probably named for the Roman goddess of marriage, this month is one of the most popular for weddings

(5, 1).clue: It's the stretch between the tee & the green on a golf-course hole

(6, 1).clue: It's the classic song in which Frank faced off against "the final curtain"

(1, 2).clue: The New York Mets beat the Baltimore Orioles to take their first World Series in this year

(2, 2).clue: This word for an assembly of 13 witches comes from the same root as a word for a gathering of nuns

(3, 2).clue: This New Hampshire capital is home to the Franklin Pierce Law School

(4, 2).clue: "Keep your eyes wide open before marriage, half shut afterwards", he advised in "Poor Richard's Almanack"

(5, 2).clue: Someone who hides aboard a ship to obtain free transportation

(6, 2).clue: In "New York, New York" Frank sang he wanted to be "king of the hill" & "top of" this

(1, 3).clue: Cheering crowds met Allied troops liberating Rome from the Axis Powers in this year

(2, 3).clue: Though it's not one of the 10 Commandments, "Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live" is in this book of the Bible

(3, 3).clue: On Nov. 16, 1941 Berwyn, Oklahoma was renamed for this singing cowboy who owned land there

(4, 3).clue: A rose has long been a symbol of love; rearrange its letters & you get the name of this Greek god of love

(5, 3).clue: It's a popular New York City piano-making company

(6, 3).clue: Frank won an Oscar for playing the role of Maggio in this 1953 war movie

(1, 4).clue: We hadn't heard anything yet when Al Jolson sang & spoke in "The Jazz Singer", a talkie released way back in this year

(2, 4).clue: It's an "intimate" term for a cat or other animal that embodies the supernatural & helps a witch

(3, 4).clue: In 1851 Prairie Rapids, Iowa was renamed this for the Belgian site of Napoleon's last defeat

(4, 4).clue: Sort of the Sanskrit "Joy of Sex", this classic Indian love manual dates back to the 4th century B.C.

(5, 4).clue: The passage from the nose or mouth to the lungs

(6, 4).clue: Frank's last No. 1 hit was 1967's "Somethin' Stupid", a duet with her

(1, 5).clue: Roald Amundsen first reached the South Pole late in this year

(2, 5).clue: Title of a B'way play & also a Jimmy Stewart film, these 3 items are part of a Catholic rite concerning witches

(3, 5).clue: In 2006 Dick Clark's American Bandstand Theater opened in this entertainment capital in Missouri

(4, 5).clue: Traditionally, when a Jewish couple marries, it's under a canopy called this

(5, 5).clue: It's a high bridge between islands

(6, 5).clue: The first names of 2 of Frank's 4 wives

(1, 1).clue: The Nebraska city where he was born in 1913

(2, 1).clue: From the Latin for "invite", it's to strive in competition, as for a title

(4, 1).clue: Famous title of the divine coming-ashore party seen here

(5, 1).clue: Fitzgerald's translation of "The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam" is quite enthused about "this forbidden" drink

(6, 1).clue: 2 of the model numbers for these big-screen robots are the T-800 & the T-1000

(1, 2).clue: The Michigan city where he set up his law practice, before his political career

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew holds a peanut in her hand.)  A peanut is more "pea" than "nut": it's actually a legume; the nuts are seeds and the shell is properly called this

(3, 2).clue: "Herodias' Daughter Who Was Trying to Get a Head"

(4, 2).clue: This type of monkey seen here is not much bigger than the rodent whose name it bears

(5, 2).clue: Written in September 1819, his "To Autumn" begins, "Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness."

(6, 2).clue: In "Blade Runner", this is the term for the androids that Rick Deckard is tracking down & killing

(1, 3).clue: The man he succeeded as vice president

(2, 3).clue: This 3-letter word can refer to a globe or an eyeball

(3, 3).clue: "How You Might Address an Upper-Class Married Creature of the Order Lepidoptera"

(4, 3).clue: Somewhat fancifully, a Mexican fashion favorite lends its name to this galaxy pictured here

(5, 3).clue: Shortly after writing "I Have a Rendezvous With" this, WWI poet Alan Seeger met it

(6, 3).clue: This Comedy Central series featured fighting robot vehicles trying to disable each other

(1, 4).clue: The investigative body to which Ford was appointed on November 29, 1963

(2, 4).clue: A water spirit, or to put the kibosh on something

(3, 4).clue: "A Hairstylist in an Andalusian City in Spain"

(4, 4).clue: In the 16th century, the Ottoman Empire controlled what is today this country

(5, 4).clue: Though born on Long Island, in his poetry he was "Walt Whitman, a Kosmos, of" this island "the Son"

(6, 4).clue: The 1957 MGM film "The Invisible Boy" featured this "Forbidden Planet" robot turning in his 2nd mechanical role on film

(1, 5).clue: The location where Pres. George W. Bush eulogized Ford as "the best of America"

(2, 5).clue: Arabic for "son of", it's often used in personal names

(3, 5).clue: "Masculine Singular Ablative in Latin for Faithful or True"

(5, 5).clue: "A terrible beauty is born", this Irishman wrote on "Easter, 1916"

(6, 5).clue: This series featured 2 robots & one human making sarcastic comments while watching B movies

(0, 0).clue: Carel Fabritius, whose self-portrait is seen here, is considered this man's greatest pupil
